dataModel.title: Vegetation Database Component Description: --all modules--
dataModel.versionDesc: This version of the VegBank database model includes changes to make reference one set of tables (no more commReference, plantReference, cititation). level and parent have been moved to Status for plant and comm modules.
dataModel.author: M. Lee

entity.entitySummary: This table store the concepts (assertions) that are linked to community names through the commUsage table.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commConcept table.
Foreign key into the commName table providing the name used for the community when it was defined by usage in a publication (which could be this database).

Foreign key into the Reference table to identify a reference in which the community was identified by a name. This could be a regular publication, or a self reference created by completing the commDescription field in reference
The commDescription is a description of the community concept by the party that contributed the concept.

entity.entitySummary: This table correlates multiple community concepts as they change through time in the perception of a party

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the communityCorrelation table.
This is the foreign key into the CommStatus table "pointing" to a concept no longer viewed as standard by the party.
This is the foreign key into the communityConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The two concepts are exactly the same.
The reference concept (referenced in table:Status) fully contains the correlated concept (referenced in table:Concept), but also includes additional entities.
The reference concept is fully included in the correlated concept, but the latter concept contains additional entities.
The two concepts are not exactly the same. This leaves the possibilties that the reference concept is greater than, less than, overlapping, similar, or disjunct relative to the correlated concept.
The two concepts contain at least one common entity, and each concept also contains at least one entity that the other does not contain. Neither concept is fully contained in the other.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual.
The two concepts in question contain no common entities.
Although some correlation is likely, the party responsible for the this correlation has not made a determination.

attribute.attDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the start date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.
This is the stop date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores tracks the lineage of vegetation community concepts.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commLineage table.
This is the foreign key into the commStatus table "pointing" to a parent concept.
This is the foreign key into the commStatus table "pointing" to a child concept.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores vegetation community names

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commName table.
The community name.
Foreign key into reference to identify the source of the name.
Field stores the date that the name was entered into the database.

entity.entitySummary: Party contributing commuinity taxonomic perspective; may be either an individual or an organization.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique party.
Salutation preceding one's given name.
One's first name.
One's middle name or initial, if any.
Name shared in common to identify the members of a family, as distinguished from each member's given name.
Name of an organization.
Recursive foreign key to current name of this party.
Instructions for contacting a party.
Recursive foreign key to the Party who owns this party record and who has exclusive rights to update the information content.

entity.entitySummary: This table store the status of a community concept as perceived by a party at a time.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commStatus table.
Foreign key to identify the concept to which a party assigns a status
Link to a reference where the status was reported
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)

The commParent is a recursive key to the concept of the parent level in the classification hierarchy. For example, if this concept were at the association level, the parentClass would be a concept that is the parent alliance type.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: A grouping of associations with a characteristic physiognomy and habitat and which share one or more diagnostic species typically found in the uppermost or dominant stratum of the vegetation. (This definition includes both floristic and physiognomic criteria, in keeping with the integrated physiognomic-floristic hierarchy of the NVC. It is similar to the FGDC 1997 definition: a physiognomically uniform group of Associations sharing one or more diagnostic (dominant, differential, indicator, or character) species, which, as a rule, are found in the uppermost stratum of the vegetation.)
A recurring plant community with a characteristic range in species composition, specific diagnostic species, and a defined range in habitat conditions and physiognomy or structure.

the first physiognomic level in the NVC hierarchy; based on the structure of the vegetation and determined by the relative percentage of cover and the height of the dominant, life forms (Grossman et al. 1998).

a level in the NVC based on physiognomic grouping of vegetation units with broadly defined environmental and additional physiognomic factors in common. (FGDC 1997). Grossman et al. (1998) clarified this definition as a level in the classification hierarchy below subgroup which represents vegetation types that share a definite physiognomy or structure within broadly defined environmental factors, relative landscape positions, or hydrologic regimes. Both of these definitions derive from Whittaker 1962: a "community type defined by dominance of a given growth form in the uppermost stratum of the community, or by a combination of dominant growth forms."

the level in the classification hierarchy below subclass based on leaf characters and identified and named in conjunction with broadly defined macroclimatic types to provide a structural-geographic orientation (Grossman et al. 1998).

attribute.attDefinition: The commLevel attribute specifies a level in the taxonomic hierarchy to which a class belongs. Field commLevel is an open list with the possible values defined by the classification system employed. If the party responsible for the record in the commStatus table is using the U.S. National Vegetation Classification, the acceptable levels are defined in the Vegetation Classification Standard of the Federal Geographic Data Committee as adopted June 1997. The standard is available at http://biology.usgs.gov/fgdc.veg/standards/vegstd.htm and the allowable entries for each of the physiognomic levels are listed in the appendix (see http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/documents/standards/vegetation/tables19-41.pdf). If the Braun-Blanquet classification system is employed, the acceptable values are defined in the International Code of Phytosociological Nomenclature (Weber, H.E., Moravec, J. Theurillat, J.-P. 2000. Journal of Vegetation Science. 11: 739-769).
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party started.
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party ended.
Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment
Foreign key that identifies the party that made the status assignment

entity.entitySummary: This table links a community name with a concept.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the communityUsage table.
This field is the foreign key into the commName table.
This field is the foreign key into the commConcept table.
This is the date on which the party applied the name to the concept.
This is the date on which the party ceased to apply the name to the concept.
This field shows the status of the application of the name to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined).
Foreign key that identifies the party that used the class concept with the name.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
Ecological Society of American Vegetation Classification Panel. 2003. Guidelines ver. 2
International Code of Phytosociological Nomenclature (2000. J. Veg. Sci. 11: 739-769)

attribute.attNotes: Like FGDC of Forest Cover Class.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., Scientific, Spanish common).

entity.entitySummary: This table store the concepts that are linked to plant names through the plantUsage table.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the commConcept table.
This is a foreign key into the plant name list, the entery in which when combined wiht a reference constitutes a concept.
This is a foreign key to the reference in which the name was used, thereby defining a concept.
The plantDescription is a description of the plantConcept by the party contributing the plantConcept.

entity.entitySummary: This table correlates multiple plant concepts as they change through time.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantCorrelation table.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a concept no longer viewed as standard by the party.
This is the foreign key into the plantConcept table "pointing" to a concept recognized by the party as a "standard" concept.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The two concepts are exactly the same.
The reference concept (referenced in table:Status) fully contains the correlated concept (referenced in table:Concept), but also includes additional entities.
The reference concept is fully included in the correlated concept, but the latter concept contains additional entities.
The two concepts, are not exactly the same. This leaves the possibilties that the reference concept is greater than, less than, overlapping, similar, or disjunct relative to the correlated concept.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual, and each concept also contains at least one individual that the other does not contain. Neither concept is fully contained in the other.
The two concepts contain at least one common individual.
The two concepts in question contain no common individuals.
Although some correlation is likely, the party responsible for the this correlation has not made a determination.

attribute.attDefinition: This is the descriptive attribute that is used to relate the congruence between two concepts.
This is the start date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.
This is the stop date for recognition by a party of a correlation between two concepts.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores tracks the lineage of plant taxon concepts.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantLineage table.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a child concept.
This is the foreign key into the plantStatus table "pointing" to a parent concept.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plant names

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantName table.
The plant name.
Foreign key into the reference table to identify the original source of the name (usually the type description).
Field stores the date that the name was entered into the database.

entity.entitySummary: Party contributing plant taxonomic perspective; may be either an individual or an organization.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique party.
Salutation preceding one's given name.
One's first name.
One's middle name or initial, if any.
Name shared in common to identify the members of a family, as distinguished from each member's given name.
Name of an organization.
Recursive foreign key to current name of this party.
Instructions for contacting a party.
Recursive foreign key to the Party who owns this party record and who has exclusive rights to update the information content.

entity.entitySummary: This table store the status of a community concept as perceived by a party at a time.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantStatus table.
Foreign key to identify the concept to which a party assigns a status
Link to a reference where the status was reported
Status of the concept by the party (accepted, not accepted, undetermined)
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party started.
This is the date for which the status assignment by the party ended.
Comments by party providing rationale for status assignment
Foreign key that identifies the party that made the status assignment

The plantParent is a recursive key to the concept of the parent level in the classification hierarchy. For example if this plantConcept were at the genus level the plantParent would be the plantConcept that is the family level (or subfamily level).
The classLevel attribute specifies a level in the taxonomic hierarcy that a class belongs.

entity.entitySummary: This table links a plant name with a concept.

attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value to each unique record in the plantUsage table.
This field is the foreign key into the plantName table.
This field is the foreign key into the plantConcept table.
This is the date on which the party applied the name to the concept.
This is the date on which the party ceased to apply the name to the concept.
This field shows the status of the application of the name to the concept by the party (standard, not standard, undetermined).
Foreign key that identifies the party that uses the concept with the name.
This is the name of the classification system wherein the name is applied (e.g., EnglishCommon or Scientific).

entity.entitySummary: This table contains the postal address, email address and/or organizational affiliation for a parties at the time of a plot event.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the address table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique party address (note that a single party may have multiple addresses but that only one may be 'current').

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the party to which this address applies

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to an organization with which a party is affiliated
Position of party within organization.
email address
Address line for the location (Street name, box number, suite).
City of the location.
State, province of the location.
Zip code or other postal code.
Country of the physical address.
This flag signifies whether the address is the current address of the party.

The first database date on which the address/organization information applied (have a discrete date on which address is known to applied -- not necessarily the first date on which the address applied).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores valid role codes for use in contributor tables

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the aux_Role table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique role code
constraining list of role codes for *Contributor tables
Description of the role
1=required, 2=allowed
1=required, 2=allowed
1=required, 2=allowed
1=required, 2=allowed

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about references cited within the database

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the reference table.
The 'shortName' field provides a concise or abbreviated name that describes the resource that is being documented.
Describes the type of reference this generic type is being used to represent. Examples: book, journal article, webpage.

The formal title given to the work by its author or publisher. The 'title' field provides a description of the resource that is being documented that is long enough to differentiate it from other similar resources.
A second, higher order title where appropriate, which in the case of a reference to a chapter is the Book title, and in the case of a Conference Presentation is the Name of the Conference.

The 'pubDate' field represents the date that the resource was published. The format should be represented as: CCYY, which represents a 4 digit year, or as CCYY-MM-DD, which denotes the full year, month, and day. Note that month and day are optional components. Formats must conform to ISO 8601. For example: 1999-10-26
The date the resource being referenced was accessed. This is useful if the resource is could be changed after formal publication, such as websites or databases.
The date the conference was held.
Foreign key into the journal table to identify the journal of this reference.
The volume field is used to describe the volume of the journal in which the article appears.
The issue field is used to describe the issue of the journal in which the article appears.
The page range field is used for the beginning and ending pages of the journal article that is being documented.
The total pages field is used to describe the total number of pages in the book that is being described.
The organization that physically put together the report and publishes it.
The location at which the work was published. This is usually the name of the city in which the publishing house produced the work.
The ISBN, or International Standard Book Number that has been assigned to this literature resource.
The edition field is to document the edition of the generic reference type that is being described.
Number of volumes in a collection
The chapter number of the chapter of a book that is being described.
The report number field is used to describe the unique identification number that has been issued by the report institution for the report being described.
The type of personal communication. Could be an email, letter, memo, transcript of conversation either hardcopy or online.
The degree field is used to describe the name or degree level for which the thesis was completed.
A URL (Uniform Resource Locator) from which this resource can be downloaded or additional information can be obtained.

A Digital int Identifier - a digital identifier for any object of intellectual property. A DOI provides a means of persistently identifying a piece of intellectual property on a digital network and associating it with related current data. (www.doi.org)
This field provides any information that is not characterized by the other resource metadata fields. Example: Copyright 2001, Robert Warner

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about identifiers that can be used to indicate a particular reference.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceAltIdent table.
Foreign key into the reference table to indicate which reference is referenced by this alternate identifier.

The data management system within which an identifier is in scope and therefore unique. This is typically a URL (Uniform Resource Locator) that indicates a data management system. All identifiers that share a system must be unique. In other words, if the same identifier is used in two locations with identical systems, then by definition the objects at which they point are in fact the same object. Example(s): http://metacat.somewhere.org/svc/mc/

An additional, secondary identifier for this entity. The primary identifier belongs in the reference table, but additional identifiers that are used to label this entity, possibly from different data management systems, can be listed here. Example: VCR3465

entity.entitySummary: This table links reference parties with references and shows how a contribution was made by the party.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceContributor table.
Foreign key into the reference table to indicate which reference is referenced by this alternate identifier.
Foreign key into the referenceParty table to indicate which person contributed.
Use this field to describe the role the party played with respect to the resource. Some potential roles include technician, reviewer, principal investigator, and many others.
Numerical order in which this contributor's name should be in the order of contributors, if applicable. Examples: 1 [for the first author], 2, [for the second author], etc.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about parties that contributed to a reference.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceParty table.
Type of Party this record refers to: usually person or institution. Type determines rules for which fields must be completed.

This field is intended to be used instead of a particular person or full organization name. If the associated person that holds the role changes frequently, then Position Name would be used for consistency. Note that this field, used in conjunction with 'organizationName' and 'individualName' make up a single logical originator. Because of this, an originator with only the individualName of 'Joe Smith' is NOT the same as an originator with the name of 'Joe Smith' and the organizationName of 'NSF'. Also, the positionName should not be used in conjunction with individualName unless only that individual at that position would be considered an originator for the data package. If a positionName is used in conjunction with an organizationName, then that implies that any person who currently occupies said positionName at organizationName is the originator of the data package. Example(s): Niwot Ridge Data Manager
The salutation field is used in addressing an individual with a particular title, such as Dr., Ms., Mrs., Mr., etc.

The given name field is used for the all names, except the surname, of the individual associated with the resource. Possible usages include: first name and middle name, first name and middle initials, first name, etc. Example(s): Jo, Jo R., Jo R.W., John Robert Peter
The surname field is used for the last name of the individual associated with the resource.
A suffix or suffix abbreviation that follows a name. Examples: Jr., Senior, III, etc.

The responsible party field contains the full name of the organization that is associated with the resource. This field is intended to describe which institution or overall organization is associated with the resource being described. Note that this field, used in conjunction with 'individualName' and 'positionName' make up a single logical originator. Because of this, an originator with only the individualName of 'Joe Smith' is NOT the same as an originator with the name of 'Joe Smith' and the organizationName of 'NSF'. Also, the positionName should not be used in conjunction with individualName unless only that individual at that position would be considered an originator for the data package. If a positionName is used in conjunction with an organizationName, then that implies that any person who currently occupies said positionName at organizationName is the originator of the data package. Example(s): National Center for Ecological Analysis and Synthesis
Recursive Foreign key into the referenceParty table to indicate the current name of the party.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about journals used as part of a reference.

attribute.attDefinition: Primary key for the referenceJournal table.

The name of the journal, magazine, newspaper, zine, etc... in which the article was published. Example(s): Ecology, New York Times, Harper's, Canadian Journal of Botany/Revue Canadienne de Botanique ,The Journal of the American Medical Association
The ISSN, or International Standard Serial Number that has been assigned to this literature resource. Example(s): ISSN 1234-5679
Standard abbreviation or shorter name of the journal. Example(s): Can. J. Bot./Rev. Can. Bot., JAMA

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about who participated in a classification event
entity.entityDescription: This table serves as an interesection entity used to link a party with a specific plot classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the classContributor table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique contribution to the classificaiton of a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commClass table.
attribute.attDefinition: Observation classification event to which the contributor is associated.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the party that contributed to the classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the aux_Role table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the role that the party had in the classification event (e.g., classifier, consultant, research advisor).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores general information about classification events where one or more community concepts were applied to a specific Observation by one or more parties.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the commClass table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique observation classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation table identifying which observation is being classified.
Start date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.
Stop date for the application of a vegetation class to a plot observation by one or more parties.
Classification informed by simple inspection of data.
Classification informed by inspection of floristic composition tables.
Classification informed by use of multivariate numerical tools.
Classification informed by use of automated expert system.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a publication wherein the observation was classified.
Notes about the classification event by the parties participating in the event. This might include the purpose or rationale for the classification.

entity.entitySummary: This table tracks the assignment of specific community concepts to plot observations

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the communityInterpretation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique assignment of a community concept to a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commClassification table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the commClassification table identifying the specific classification event.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the commConcept table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the communityConcept table identifying the specific community concept being applied.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: No doubt about the match. Perfect fit.
This answer is absolutely unacceptable. Unambiguously incorrect.
Good match with the concept. Unambiguously correct.
Maybe not the best possible answer but it is acceptable; this answer does not pose a problem to the user. Correct.
Not a good answer. There is something about the plot that makes the answer understandable, but there is clearly a better answer. This answer would pose a problem for users. Incorrect.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of fit with the community concept being assigned (e.g., fits concept well, fits but not typal, possible fit, just outside concept).

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The party making the community interpretation has a high confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation. A party can have high confidence that a plot has a fit of "absolutely wrong" for a particular community.
The party making the community interpretation has a low confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.
The party making the community interpretation has a medium amount of confidence in the accuracy of this interpretation.

attribute.attDefinition: Indicates the degree of confidence of the interpretor(s) in the interpretation made. This can reflect the level of familiarity with the classification or the sufficiency of information about the plot (e.g., High, Moderate, Low).

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the reference from which information on the community concept was obtained during the classification event. (A case could be made for thisd being moved to reference.)
Notes pertaining to the classification analysis and decision.

This assignment is the type description for the community concept, as indicated in the publication referenced in commClass.classPublication_ID (NOT the commAuthority_ID of this commInterpretation table).
Typal plot for the Braun-Blanquet community name.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores the definitions of each coverclass unit associated with each coverclass method.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the coverIndex table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique coverclass associated index value.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the coverMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Links to a specific cover scale.
The name or label used in the coverclass scale for this specific specific coverclass.
Upper limit, in percent, associated with the specific coverCode.

This is the lower limit, in percent, associated with a specific coverCode. Where a cover scale has a non-quantitative lower or upper value, as in the "+" of the Braun-Blanquet scale, it is necessary to provide an approximation with "0" being the lower limit of the bottom most class.

A middle value (usually mean or geometric mean) between the upperLimit and lowerLimt stored by the database for each taxon observation and used for all coverclass conversions and interpretations. This is assigned by the author of the cover class schema.
Description of the specific coverclass. This is particularly helpful in the case that there is no numeric value that can be applied.

entity.entitySummary: This table associates a cover scale recognized by the plot data collectors with a set of coverclasses specified in the coverIndex table. This table, together with the coverIndex table, defines a coverclass method.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the coverMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique coverclass methodology.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign Key into the reference table, linking the defining reference to a cover method.
Name of the coverclass method (e.g., Braun-Blanquet, Barkman, Domin, Daubenmire, Carolina Vegetation Survey, etc.).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores the values of user-defined variables.
entity.entityDescription: This table stores values associated with specific user-defined variables identified in the userDefined table.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the definedValue table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique defined value.
Link to a specific user-defined variable defined in the userDefined table.
The value of the user-defined variable.

attribute.attNotes: Pseudokey for the table with which this value should be associated
attribute.attDefinition: The numeric value of the record number (primary key) that this user-defined value would have if it were in the table identified by USERDEFINED_ID.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plot observation information pertaining toobserver estamation of the disturbance history of the plot.
entity.entityDescription: disturbanceObs is a child of observation; a plot might experience many types of disturbance unique to different observation events.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique disturbance observation..

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key that points to the parent observation for this disturbance record
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation event with which this report of a disturbance event is associated.
The type of disturbance being reported

attListItem.attListValueDesc: No disturbance of this type was observed on the plot. This may be a useful observation where certain types of disturbance are expected, but no signs of such disturbance were found.

attribute.attDefinition: Intensity or degree of the disturbance.
Estimated time in years since the disturbance event.
Percent of the plot that experienced the event.
Text description of details of the disturbance and its impact on the vegetation.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about graphical files related to vegetation plot observations
entity.entityDescription: Graphical files can include, among other formats: gif, jpeg, and tif file formats. Because many graphical files, especially remote sensing digital photographs, may be too large to be stored within the database, a graphicLocation may be given as an altern

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique graphic idem.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link from a graphic file to a specific plot observation.
Name of the graphic file.
Where the graphic is located, if not in the database
Description of the graphical file and associated metadata such as contributor, author, sensor, etc.
The type of the graphical file format (e.g. gif, tif, ,jpeg).
Date that the graphic was produced.

attribute.attNotes: may be constrainted by a maximum size
attribute.attDefinition: The graphical file data. - Max = 5 M total per plot

entity.entitySummary: This tables stores information about the various 'named places' that a plot may have been located within. Such places could include geographic regions, study sites, ownership units, managed units, any placename in the USGS glossary (http://www-nmd.usgs.go

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique named place.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: area, country, or territory
county, canton, or parrish
User named places
region or state or province
A non-standard or generic ecoregion that is not specifically menioned in this list.

attribute.attDefinition: Name of the system of names. These can be treated as points as with placenames, or as a coverage or set of polygons (e.g., geographic area names, HUC codes, Ecoregions, Quadrangles).

The name of a place in or at which a plot is located. The system "Geographic Name" is an open list defined within this table. The other systems are generally closed lists constrained by aux_tables. These include at least USGSQuad, Continent, Country, State, County, HUC, and Ecoregion.
This is the description of a named place.
Optional code for location identification

Although sometwhat redundant with the owner information contained in observationContributor with roleCode of owner, this allows the program to provide ownership information automatically. The ownership field supercedes this field in priority.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a reference that contains further information on the named place.

entity.entitySummary: This table is where notations associated with table records are stored
entity.entityDescription: All notes associated with plots and plot observations are stored in this table. These notes can be linked to any table, record and attribute via the noteLink table.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the note table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique note.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the notelink table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the noteLink table via which a note is associated with a table, record and attribute.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the party table to identify the party that contributed the note.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the aux_role table
attribute.attDefinition: What role was the party palying when the note was applied?
The date on which the note was stored in the database.

The type of note: Database Management, Observation Author, Database User and Internal. "Database Managment" notes are those added by the management team and may be queried and viewed by the public. "Database Use" notes are those entered by the users of the database and are publicly viewable. "Internal" notes are for management to use internally and will not be broadcast.
The text of the note.

entity.entitySummary: This table links a note made by a database user or manager to a specific table, record and attribute in the database.
entity.entityDescription: This table was developed with the goal of keeping all the notes associated with the plots in a single table rather than distributed in many tables across the database.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the noteLink table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique noteLink.
Name of the table that the note is associated with.
Name of the attribute in the table (stored in tableName) that the note is associated with.
The record number (row) containing the value with which the note is associated (which translates to the primary key value for the table wherein the record is stored).

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plot observation results that might vary between official observation events.
entity.entityDescription: Observation is a child of plot in recognition of the fact that a plot may be resampled and that some of the environmental conditions may change between resampling events.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the observation table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique plot observation.
Link to data from the previous observation of this plot.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the plot table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to data and metadata that do not change between observations and which are stored in the plot table.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the project table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link between an observation and the project within which the observation was made
This is the code or name that the author uses to identify this plot observation event. Where a plot has only one observation, this will often equal plot.authorPlotCode.
The date of the observation, or the first day if the observation spanned more than one day.
If the observation event spanned more than a single day, this is the last day on which observations were made.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: The exact date of the observation - within one day.
Within one month of the observation.

attribute.attDefinition: Estimated accuracy of the observation date.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the coverMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the scale used to estimate taxon cover. The database stores estimated cover to the nearest percent, but the conversion details are recovered by reference to the specific scale employed.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratumMethod table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the definitions of strata used in recording taxon-specific values of cover.
Lower diameter limit in centimeters for inclusion of a tree in the stem count (stemCount).
Additional metadata helpful for understanding how the data were collected during the observation event.

the total surface area (in m2) used for cover estimates and for which a complete species list is provided. If subplots were used, this would be the total area of the subplots without intersticial space.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Cover based on observation of an entire plot consisting of a single contiguous area of land.
Cover based on observation of multiple randomly dispersed within the overall plot.
Cover based on observation of multiple subplots arranged in a regular pattern within the overall plot.
Cover based on observation of multiple subplots haphazardly arranged within the overall plot.
Cover based on observation of a single contiguous area of land of less spatial extent than the entire plot.

attribute.attDefinition: Were cover values for the total taxon list collected from one contiguous area or dispersed subplots (e.g., continguous, dispersed-regular, dispered-random)?
TRUE indicates that taxonObservation.taxonCover was automatically calculated from the values of all stratumObservation.taxonStratumCover
the total surface area (in m2) observed for recording woody stem data
The method used to obtain basal area or tree stem data (e.g., full census, point quarter, random pairs, Bitterlich, other).
Location where the hard data reside and any access instructions.
This is the effort spent making the observations as estimated by the party that submitted the data (e.g., Very thorough, Average, Hurried description).

entity.attribute:
plotValidationLevel implementation yes <<<<<<< db_model_vegbank.xml
Integer ======= Integer
>>>>>>> 1.14 n/a n/a closed
1 (1) sufficient for determining type occurrence 1
2 (2) sufficient for inclusion in a classification revision 2
3 (3) fully compliant with recommendations 3
closed list Quality of plot as determined by an automated filter system, including values such as (1) sufficient for determining type occurrence, (2) sufficient for inclusion in a classification revision, and (3) fully compliant with recommendations.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: between 85% and 95% of all taxa were identified to species level; search was thorough.
at least 85% of all taxa were identified to species level; search was not so thorough.
at least 95% of all taxa were identified to species level; search was thorough.
less than 70% of all taxa were identified to species level.
between 70% and 85% of all taxa were identified to species level; search was thorough.
between 70% and 85% of all taxa were identified to species level; search was not so thorough.

attribute.attDefinition: Subjective assessment of floristic quality by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low).

Subjective assessment of the taxonmic quality of the bryophye data by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low, Very incomplete,absent).

Subjective assessment of the taxonmic quality of the lichen data by the party that submitted the plot (e.g., Highest, High, High but incomplete, Moderate, Moderate and incomplete, Low, Very incomplete,absent).
Additional unstructured observations useful for understanding the ecological attributes and significance of the plot observations.
Unstructured observations on the landscape context of the observed plot.
How homogeneous was the community (e.g., homogeneous, compositionial trend across plot, conspicuous inclusions, irregular mosaic or pattern).
Season expression of the community (e.g., typical growing season, vernal, aestival, wet, autumnal, winter, dry, irregular ephemerals present).
How representative was the plot of the stand?
Total basal area of woody stems (in m2/ha).
What is the hydrologic regime, which is a refelction of frequency and duration of flooding)?
How moist was the soil at the sampling event?
How well drained is the site. Soil drainage classes conform to the FGDC Soil Geographic Data Standards, September 1997. http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/documents/standards/soils/soil997.PDF

attListItem.attListValueDesc: 0.5 to 30 ppt
less than 0.5 ppt
greater than 30 ppt

attribute.attDefinition: How saline is the water, if a flooded community?
For aquatic or marine vegetation, what was the water depth in m.
For aquatic or marine vegetation, what was the closest distance to shore in m.
Median depth to bedrockor permafrost in m (usually from averaging multiple probe readings).
Depth of the curficial organic layer, where present, in centimeters.
Percent of surface that is exposed bedrock.
Percent of surface that is exposed rock and gravel.
Percent of surface that is wood.
Percent of surface that is litter.
Percent of surface that is bare soil.
Percent of surface that is water.
Percent of surface that belong to an additional itemized category
Name of additional itemized groundcover category (e.g., beer cans).

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Ages of individuals are uneven so that this community does not fit neatly into the succession model.

attribute.attDefinition: How mature is the stand. Could be young, mature but even-aged, old-growth, etc.
Description of the assumed successional status of the plot. This descriptionis of necessity highly subjective.
Height of the tree layer in m.
Height of the shrub layer in m.
Height of the field layer in m.
Height of the nonvascular layer in m.
Height of the submerged layer in m.
Total cover of the tree layer in percent.
Total cover of the shrub layer in percent.
Total cover of the field layer in percent.
Total cover of the nonvascular layer in percent.
Total cover of the floating layer in percent.
Total cover of the submerged layer in percent.
Which of the six standard strata is dominant?

attListItem.attListValueDesc: larger woody plants, mostly well above 5 m tall
mainly conifers - pine, spruce, larch, redwood, etc.
leaves shed in the temperate zone winter, or in the tropical dry season
many tropical and subtropical trees, mostly with medium-sized leaves
armed with spines, in many cases with compound, deciduous leaves, often reduced in size
with smaller, tough, evergreen leaves
primarily cacti and succulent euphorbs
rosette trees, unbranched with a crown of large leaves
rosette trees, unbranched with a crown of large leaves
arborescent grasses with woody-like stems
other type of tree not on the list
smaller woody plants, mostly below 5 m tall
mainly conifers - juniper, yew, etc.
leaves shed in the temperate zone winter, or in the tropical dry season
many tropical and temperate shrubs, mostly with medium to small-sized leaves
armed with spines, in many cases with compound, deciduous leaves, often reduced in size
with smaller, tough, evergreen leaves
rosette shrubs, unbranched with a short crown of leaves
low shrubs spreading near the ground surface, less than 50 cm high
suffrutescent, i.e., with the upper parts of the stems and branches dying back in unfavorable seasons
cacti, certain euphorbias, etc.
other type of shrub not on the list
plants without perennial aboveground woody stems
herbs other than ferns and graminoids
grasses, sedges, and other grass like plants
pteridophytes -ferns, clubmosses, horsetails, etc
floating and submergent
other type of herbacious species not on the list
plants growing wholly above the ground surface on other plants
woody climbers or vines
other type of species not on the list

attribute.attDefinition: The predominant growth form?

attribute.attDefinition: The third-most predominant growthform
Total cover of the predominant growthform?
Total cover of the second-most predominant growthform?
Total cover of the third-most predominent growthform?
Foreign key into table of soil taxa within the USDA classification hierarchy, including Order, Suborder, Greatgroup, Subgroup, Family and Series.
How was the soil taxon determined (e.g., field observation, map, other sources)?
TRUE indicates that public notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that nonpublic management notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that revisions exist in vegPlot.Revision

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about which parties contributed to specific plot observation events.
entity.entityDescription: This table serves as an interesection that links a party with a specific plot observation event. Note that there is no plotContributor table because all contributions take place at a particular observation, such as the first observation.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique contribution to an observation event.

attribute.attNotes: This is tforeign key into the Observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key pointing to a given plot observation event to which the contribution was made.

attribute.attNotes: This is the foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key pointing to the specific party that made the contribution.

attribute.attNotes: This is the foreign key into the aux_Role table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the role that the party had in the plot obsevation (e.g., PI, contact, research advisor, field assistant, taxonomist, owner, guide, etc.).
The date of the specific contribution, which will generally be within the time span of the plot observation event defined by the obsStartDate and obsStopDate

entity.entitySummary: This table stores opinions as to whether one observation record is a synonym of another owing to double entry into the database.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the observationSynonym table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique interpretaiton of an observation as a synonym.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation table identifying which observation is being reduced to synonymy.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the observation table identifying which observation is the prefered synonym for the observation being reduced to synonym.

attribute.attNotes: This is the foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key pointing to the specific party that made the reduction to synonym.

attribute.attNotes: This is the foreign key into the aux_Role table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the role that the party had in the plot synonomization (e.g., plot author, data manager, publication author, researcher, generic user, etc.).
Start date for the synonymization event.
Stop date for the synonymization event.
Notes about the reason for the synonymization.

entity.entitySummary: Party contributing to collection or interpretation of a plot; may be either an individual or an organization.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique party.
Salutation preceding one's given name.
One's first name.
One's middle name or initial, if any.
Name shared in common to identify the members of a family, as distinguished from each member's given name.
Name of an organization.
Recursive foreign key to current name of this party.
Instructions for contacting a party.
Recursive foreign key to the Party who owns this party record and who has exclusive rights to update the information content.

entity.entitySummary: This table is the intersection between the plot table and the namedPlace table and is used for querying for plots located in a named place or named region in which a plot or group of plots is located.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the place table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique plot occurrence at a place.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the plot table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a specific plot.
TRUE If occurrence is calculated based on geocoordinates, FALSE if assigned by the author (If, both methods used, the author assigned value takes priority).

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the namedPlace table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a specific named place or region

entity.entitySummary: This table stores general, constant information about the a given plot
entity.entityDescription: plot contains Plot location, dimension, and similarly constant site data, plus metadata that need be stored only once. Transient observational information (procured during the first or subsequent observation events) are stored separately in observation

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique plot.
Author's Plot number/code, or the original plot number if taken from literature.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the source reference from which this plot record was taken
Link to the parent plot when plot is nested within another plot.
Latitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum =WGS84
Longitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum = WGS84
Estimated accuracy of the location of the plot. Plot origin has a 95% or greater probability of being within this many meters of the reported location.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Public
1 km radius
10 km radius
100 km radius
Location embargo
Public embargo on data
Full embargo on data

attribute.attDefinition: Are the data to be considered confidential? 0=no, 1= 1km radius, 2=10km radius, 3=100km radius, 4=location embargo, 5=public embargo on all plot data, 6=full embargo on all plot data. This applies also to region.
The reason for confidentiality. This field should not be open to public view. Reasons might include specific rare species, ownership, prepublication embargo, or many other reason
Latitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum =WGS84, fuzzing applied
Longitude of the plot origin in degrees and decimals, datum = WGS84, fuzzing applied
Original E-W coordinate as recorded by the author
Original N-S coordinate as recorded by the author
Original UTM zone reported by the author
Original datum reported by the author
Original location as described by author (eg Town-Range-Section)
Text description that provides information useful for plot relocation.

This element stores the azimuth of the x-axis used to describe the relative coordinate system for plot shape (dsgpoly) and other spatial information about the plot. Typically the azimuth is parallel to the long axis of the plot (in the case of a rectangle).

This field is a text string containing the points circumscribing a plot area. These points are anticipated to have been collected using tapes, GPS, or calculated from the plot shape and area. Points are x-y coordinates in m relative to plot origin.
Shape of the plot area.
Total area of the plot in m2. If many subplots, this area includes the subplots and the intersticial space

attListItem.attListValueDesc: greater than 100x plot size
10-100x plot size
3-10x plot size
greater than 1000x plot size
1-3x plot size
less than 1x plot size

attribute.attDefinition: The extent of this community occurrence in relation to the plot size: very extensive (>1000x plot), extensive (>100x plot), large (10-100x plot), small (3-10x plot), very small (1-3x plot).
Brief description of strategy for determining plot placement within the stand.
Is the plot monumented so as to assure permanence? If so, this should be described in the layoutNarrative
Text description of and the rationale for the layout of the plot.
The elevation of the plot origin in meters above sea level.
The accuracy of the elevation in percentage of the elevation reported.
Meters of difference in elevations of the high and low points in the plot.
Representative azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees); if too flat to determine = -1; if too irregular to determine = -2.
Minimum azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees), counterclockwise from representative azmuth.
Maximum azimuth of slope gradient (0-360 degrees), clockwise from representative azmuth
Representative inclination of slope in degrees; if too irregular to determine, = -1.
Minimum inclindation of slope in degrees.
Maximum inclination of slope in degrees.

attListItem.attListValueDesc: dipslope
depression
narrow valley bottom, gully arroyo
bank
mesa, high flat
shoulder slope, upper slope, convex creep slope
crest, summit, ridge
terrace, low flat
lower slope, foot slope, colluvial footslope
transportational midslope, middle slope
ledge, terracette
alluvial toeslope

attribute.attDefinition: Position of the plot on land surface (e.g., Summit, shoulder, upper slope, middle slope, lower slope, toeslope, no slope, channel bed, dune swale, pond).
Landform type.

attListItem.attListValue: Aeolian Deposits: Aeolian sand flats and cover sands
Slope and Modified Deposits: Solifluction, landslide
Slope and Modified Deposits: Talus and scree slopes

attribute.attDefinition: Surficial deposits represent the parent material that are the geologic or organic precursors to the soil. They may either have been deposited by geologic (wind, ice, gravity or water) or biologic (organic) activity, or formed in place more-or-less directly from rocks and minerals below.
RockType values conform to the lithic types in the FGDC Soil Geographic Data Standards, September 1997. http://www.fgdc.gov/standards/documents/standards/soils/soil997.PDF (pages 56-59).
TRUE indicates that public notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that nonpublic management notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that revisions exist in vegPlot.Revision

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about a project established to collect vegetation plot data.
entity.entityDescription: Each plot originates as part of a project. A project can contain from one tomany plots.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the project table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique project.
Project name as defined by the principal investigator.
Short description of the project including the original purpose for conducting the project. This can be viewed as the project abstract plus supporting metadata.
Project start date.
Project stop date.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about a party contributing to a project.
entity.entityDescription: This table serves as an intersection entity used to 'link' a party with a specific project wherin vegetation plots are described.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the projectContributor table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique contribution to a project.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the project table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key linking the contribution to a specific project.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key linking the contribution to a specific party.
Foreign key that identifies the role that a specific party played in the project (e.g., PI, coPI, contact, author, research advisor, etc.).

entity.entitySummary: This table constitutes a log of changes in data deposited in the database.
entity.entityDescription: This table was designed to store as a single, stand-alone table information about attributes in any of the database tables.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the revision table
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique revision.
Name of the table where the change occurred.
The name of the attribute where the chance occurred.
The number of the record in which the change occurred (i.e., the value of the primary key associated with the value in which the change occured)
The date on which the revision was made.
The previous value as a character string.
The data type of the attribute changed.
Pointer to a previous record of a revision.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores observation on soil horizons made during the plot observation event.
entity.entityDescription: soilObs is child of observation in recognition of the fact that the hoizons observed vary among plot observation events as a results of real change plus changes in investigators, methods and circumstances.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique soil observation.
Link to the observation event to which this soil observation is associated.
The horizon to which this observation applies.
The depth at which the horizon observation starts.
The depth at which the horizon observation ends.
Soil color (USDA guidelines recommended).
Percent organic content of the soil (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).

attListItem.attListValueDesc: Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sands | Texture Subclass: Coarse Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sands | Texture Subclass: Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sands | Texture Subclass: Fine Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sands | Texture Subclass: Very Fine Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sands | Texture Subclass: (unspecified)
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Loamy Sands | Texture Subclass: Loamy Coarse Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Loamy Sands | Texture Subclass: Loamy Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Loamy Sands | Texture Subclass: Loamy Fine Sand

attListItem.attListValue: Loamy Sands: Loamy Very Fine Sand
attListItem.attListValueDesc: Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Loamy Sands | Texture Subclass: Loamy Very Fine Sand
Texture Group: Sandy soils | General Term: Coarse-textured | Texture Class: Loamy Sands | Texture Subclass: (unspecified)
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Loams | Texture Subclass: Coarse Sandy Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Loams | Texture Subclass: Sandy Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately coarse-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Loams | Texture Subclass: Fine Sandy Loam

attListItem.attListValue: Sandy Loams: Very Fine Sandy Loam
attListItem.attListValueDesc: Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Medium-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Loams | Texture Subclass: Very Fine Sandy Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately coarse-textured to Medium-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Loams | Texture Subclass: (unspecified)
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Medium-textured | Texture Class: Loam | Texture Subclass: Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Medium-textured | Texture Class: Silt Loam | Texture Subclass: Silt Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Medium-textured | Texture Class: Silt | Texture Subclass: Silt
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately fine-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Clay Loam | Texture Subclass: Sandy Clay Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately fine-textured | Texture Class: Clay Loam | Texture Subclass: Clay Loam
Texture Group: Loamy soils | General Term: Moderately fine-textured | Texture Class: Silty Clay Loam | Texture Subclass: Silty Clay Loam
Texture Group: Clayey soils | General Term: Fine-textured | Texture Class: Sandy Clay | Texture Subclass: Sandy Clay
Texture Group: Clayey soils | General Term: Fine-textured | Texture Class: Silty Clay | Texture Subclass: Silty Clay
Texture Group: Clayey soils | General Term: Fine-textured | Texture Class: Clay | Texture Subclass: Clay

attribute.attDefinition: Soil texture class.The texture classes sands, loamy sands, and sandy loams (plural terms) correspond to sand, loamy sand, and sandy loam (singular terms) in the textural triangle.
Percent sand in the soil hoizon.
Percent silt in the soil horizon.
Percent clay in the soil horizon.
percent coarse fragments in the soil, prior to removal for textural analysis
pH of the soil (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Cation exchange capacity (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Percent base saturation (for methods see observation.methodsNarrative).
Text description of the soil.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the aux_Soil table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique soil type
SCS Code
Name of soil type
Hierarchical level; 1=Order, 2=Suborder, 3=GreatGroup, 4=SubGroup, 5=Family, 6=Series

entity.entitySummary: This table is intended to store information about the abundance of tree stems of a specific size.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stemSize table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stem tally.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonObservation table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the taxonObservation table, thereby associating a taxon identification with the tree stem(s).

The diameter of the stem in centimeters. When diameter classes are used, the stemDiameter is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the diameter class; the offset between this and the endpoints is stored in the stemDiameterAccuracy attribute.
The accuracy of the stem diameter measurements in centimeters. This represents the distance between the diameter class midpoint and endpoint.

The measured height of the stem in meters. When height classes are used, the stemHeight is the midpoint between the low end and high end for the height class; the offset between this and the endpoint is stored in the stemHeightAccuracy field.
The accuracy of the measured height of a stem, being the offset between the midpoint of the class and the endpoint, in meters.

attribute.attNotes: The default value is 1. This field is not logically necessary, but allows for more compact entry and storage of tree stem tally data.
attribute.attDefinition: The number of stems of a single species that have these specific stem diameter and height data in common.

entity.entitySummary: This table is intended to store location information about indivdual tree stems.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stemLocation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stem observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stemSize table
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the stemSize table, thereby assigning a location to a particular stem of a specific size
Name or code applied to a specific stem in the plot. This is generally a numeric label to associate a fielddata entry with a stem in the database.
The X-coordinate of the stem position in m. The user will enter the relative position of stems with respect to the plot origin (in meters) with the x-axis defined by the plot azimuth.
The Y-coordinate of the stem position, as above.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores collective information about strata defined within a plot observation.
entity.entityDescription: This table is used to record non-species-specific information about a stratum. Examples include total cover of the stratum and maximum height of the stratum.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the stratum table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique existence of a stratum within a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the plot observation event with which this stratum observation is associated.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratumType table.
attribute.attDefinition: This attribute will link to the definition of the specific stratum observed.
Average height to the top of the stratum in meters.
Average height of the bottom of the stratum in meters.
Cover of the vegetation within the given stratum in percent.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores information about the cover of a single taxon within a specific stratum.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique observation of a taxon in a stratum.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonObservation table, which identifies the taxon.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the identification of the taxon being observed.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratum table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the specific stratum in which the taxon occurs. Because a single taxon may occur in more than one stratum, this attribute has a many to one relationship with a single taxon observation.
Percent cover of taxon in stratum

entity.entitySummary: This table links a set of strata to a sampling protocol . This table, when combined a set of linked stratum occurences, defines the strata used by a plot observer.

attribute.attNotes: Primary Key for the stratumMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique stratum methodology.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a publication defining the stratum method.
Name of the stratum method (e.g., Braun-Blanquet, TNC-ABI, NC Vegetation Survey #1, NC Vegetation Survey #2, etc.)

This field describes the general methods used for strata. For example, this field should distinguish as to whether strata are defined as including all foliage on plants that predominantly occupy the stratum regardless of the height of that foliage, or only the foliage that actually occurs within a specified vertical slice of the community.

entity.entitySummary: This table stores collective information about strata defined within a plot observation.
entity.entityDescription: This table is used to record non-species-specific information about a stratum. Examples include total cover of the stratum and maximum height of the stratum.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the stratum table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database assigned value for a unique existence of a stratum within a plot observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the stratumMethod table.
attribute.attDefinition: This attribute will link to the stratum to the stratum methodology used.
Short code used to identify the stratum
Name associated with this stratum by the stratumMethod

This field describes the specific stratum. For example, a value of "F" under stratumIndex might have a stratumName = "Floating" and a stratumDescription = "foliage floating on or near the surface of water"

entity.entitySummary: This table allows all users, including the author and/or subsequent interpreters, to attach taxon names and authorities to a specific taxon observation

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the TaxonInterpretation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique interpretation of a taxon.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonObservation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a particular taxon observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the plantConcept table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to a taxon in the plantConcept table. The entry in the plantConcept table will in turn point to a reference and a name used in the reference, thereby defining the taxon concept. The name that should be applied to the plantConcept will be party specific and will be found in the plantUsage table. For other than legacy data, the first interpretation recorded for a taxon observation should be redundant with the information contained in taxonObservation.PLANTNAME_ID + PLANTREFERENCE_ID.
The date that the interpretation was made.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the taxonName table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into the plantName (in the plantTaxa database) table to identify the name applied by the interpreter to the plantConcept. This field is not needed except in cases where there is a publication associated with the interpretation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key that identifies the party that made the interpretation, which could be the observation author.
Foreign key that identifies the role of the party making the interpretation (e.g., plot author, publication author, database manager, automated, plot contributor).
Categories for the interpretation (e.g., author, computer generated, simplified for comparative analysis, correction,finer resolution).

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: Foreign key into reference table, which identifies a publication in which the interpretation was formally made, or in which the plot was used in a formal analysis.

This interpretation corrsponds to the original interpretation of the plot author, as best as can be determined. There is no requirement that the authority match the authority of the author; only that the concepts are synonymous.
This interpretation is the most accurate and precise interpretation currently available.
These are notes that the interpreter has included with the interpretation (generally, the reason for the interpretation).
TRUE indicates that public notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that nonpublic management notes pertaining to this plot exist in "vegPlot.note"
TRUE indicates that revisions exist in vegPlot.Revision

entity.entitySummary: This table contains the author's determination of a taxon and the overall cover of that taxon.
entity.entityDescription: This table stores information about the original identification by the author of the plot and the taxonomic authority used by that author (i.e. a name - reference pair constituting a taxnomic concept). The table also contains a record of cumulative cover

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique observation of a taxon in a plot.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the Observation table.
attribute.attDefinition: Link to the parent observation event of this taxon observation.
The taxon name that the author of the plot used to refer to a taxon observed within the plot.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the reference table.
attribute.attDefinition: The authority for the taxon that was used by the plot author. If the authority is unknown the author of the plot is the authority. For other than legacy data, this field plus plantName_ID will be sufficient to determine taxonInterpretation.plantConcept_ID.
Specifics about the accession number and location of a collection made of the taxon
Overall cover of the taxon across all strata
Total basal area of the species in the stemInferenceArea in m2/ha

attribute.attNotes: The area used to infer the coverage of the taxon, if not the same as observation.taxonInferenceArea.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the area in m2 used to infer the cover of a given taxon. Generally this should be equal to observation.taxonInferenceArea, but at times this area may be larger or smaller for a specific taxon.

entity.entitySummary: Telephone numbers for the various individuals and organizations in the party table.

attribute.attNotes: Primary key for the telephone table.
attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique telephone contact record.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the party table
attribute.attDefinition: This is the 'link' between a PARTY and an entry in the TELEPHONE table.
Telephone number.
This is the type of telephone: home, work, fax, cell, secretary, other.

entity.entityDescription: This table contains the definitions of user-defined variables. The table structure stems from desire to keep the user-defined variables separate from the main body of the database.

attribute.attDefinition: Database generated identifier assigned to each unique user-defined variable.
Name of the user-defined variable.
Metadata about this user-defined variable.
Category of variable; included to facilitate queries for specific types of data.
Database data type of the user-defined variable.
Name of table with which this user-defined variable is associated. For example soilBHorizonColor may be defined by the data contributor as associated with the observation table.
